comments.commentBody:
It's really baffling and disappointing to know that even the seemingly 'enlightened & civilized' Americans
still have small-minded fellows among them... who unrepentantly prefer to chase shadows rather than the object. It's like these set of people derive a lot of joy in running their fellow humans down...even by any means. Sometimes they act as if they are God who alone has the right to judge and condemn humans.
Wont their 'chocolates & candies' be tasty if they use some measure of DIPLOMACY to constructively and objectively criticize this female Tennis Legend(of our time) that attracted many to the sport.
Talk about a Prophet not recognized and respected in her hometown.
We should all bear in mind that nobody(even an Ivy League-educated President) is perfect.
Long Live SERENA! Long Live her illustrious family!! Long Live her die-hard FANS(like me)!!!

Weprin's campaign has been horrendous. Last week he backed out of a debate at the Juniper Park Civic Association - 10,000 members and they vote en bloc...just ask Dennis Gallagher and Serf Maltese. With Turner's support in the Orthodox communities in Bkly and Queens, as well as solid support in Howard beach, Maspeth, Middle Village, Glendale and Ridgewood, Weprin is toast. Siena has Turner up by 6

Piggybacking off earlier posts here, Federer's implications that Djokovic was lucky is way out of line. He must have seen a different match than everybody else because he was thoroughly outplayed in sets 3 and 4.

And really Federer, there was nothing you could do?? Because from I saw, you still had another match point, and then you double faulted to give Djokovic the break and then you handed Djokovic another break.

It would seem like an understatement to say "Republicans MAY appear hypocritical in arguing against" extension of payroll cuts, while arguing for the extension of Bush tax cuts for the wealthy. I doubt even the most extreme Republican representatives would want to try explaining that one to their constituents.

They can use whatever buzz words and soundbites they want, until someone actually "creates" jobs, it's all hot air and emotion.

Instead of counting the number of times a word is repeated, let's count the number of unemployed who find a job next month without the magical birth/death calculations...

Nate is so right when he says that the way the question is asked often dictates the response. Everyone should know this.

My favorite is when Gallup polls "who makes up the tea party." It always comes out that they are wealthy, very well educated people. Have you ever seen who is bussed into a tea party rally? Let's just say they are the people that most need government assistance to get back on their feet. They rarely comb their hair and they wear sandals with socks, true marks of a Harvard education.

Gallup's Frank Newport doesn't like President Obama and so he wrote the most whiny article I've ever read. At one point he said something like "the President must think the American people are too stupid to understand this policy." Now please, how could he have any idea what the President is thinking. The hallmark of a Newport article is petulance. It is embarrassing--for me--to read him. I just cringe at a grown man being so obviously such a petulant child. Are his "questions" ever going to be neutral?

The larger picture is--do we want people in Congress to be trying to figure out how not to look so obstructionist? No--we want people to be figuring out how best to fix America. There is no sign that republicans, if back in power, will put America first. There are zillions of signs that they will just continue as before the "great interruption" known as Obama.

A big fundamentalist goal is marginalizing women--the fundamentalist evangelicals that populate the tea party want no birth control. Forget abortion, they would stop the manufacture of birth control. Think no one would stand for this? The Catholic church allows no birth control. Our only hope in that case would be a powerful drug company lobby. How ironic. Not to mention that I think a majority of Supreme Court justices are now Catholic. Only one more justice needed for complete control and we're back to women with 12 children.

Thanks again Nate, for a great read. You should write all polling question
Thanks for this.  I don't think many people realize just how significant this "semantic scrum" can be when it comes not only to policy debates, but also to measuring public opinion.
I think it's been clear from some of the calls we've received at home (in the district) that the pollsters were partisan.

I love the excitement and pride of little kids remarking on this extraordinary way to school....for them it must be majorly exciting and cool. But I don't get why this is considered newsworthy for adults to read.

Call me a cranky old person, but it is really truly newsworthy that kids aren't driven to school? That they actually walk a half mile on a trail? Seriously?

I know plenty of adults and kids that commute that way to work and school. I also know kids who for years have to take a boat to school from their island to another island. I know kids that take a school bus through a whole country to get to school (from Point Roberts WA, through Canada, to Washington State).

Slow news day?

As a political scientist, I know that creating public opinions is both an art and a science.  This is why I like to look at the actual wording of the question to understand what is going on.  There are more complexities too.  It matters where in the poll you ask the question.  It matters what happened with the previous questions too.  In general, it is a good bet that Obama is toast if the economy doesn't start to turn around.  He may be a nice guy, with carefully vetted speeches, but he doesn't seem presidential when you have 9.2% unemployment.
I don't think you can compare Obama to an unknown opponent since Obama has weaknesses and unknown opponent doesn't.

Yes, very smart. Eliminate all credit. let's go back to the gold standard, too.

All this hand wringing about the deficit and how much it's hurting us in far more damaging than the deficit itself.

US T bills are still by far the favored investment in the world. Where else are countries going to put their cash? With all our problems we are still the most stable and reliable economy in the world by miles.

Unlike Carl, they know that the world runs on credit had has for about the last 300-400 years.

I would be more interested in the poll numbers for resuming the issuance of United States Notes. Unless we stop borrowing and start printing real fiat currency, all of these stimulus policies will continue to fall flat on their faces.

As a Utahn, I think those insisting that Huntsman is clearly the best candidate are arguing from ignorance.  What do you know about him, really?  One of his most consistent qualities as governor was arrogance:  he knows more than anyone else.  I can't support a person who doesn't recognize what he doesn't know.  His executive appointments as governor were poor, being chosen for political reasons rather than for competence.  He didn't seem to understand when running state government was different from working for his father's company.  A person can't learn when he doesn't recognize that he has anything to learn.

Ms. Bachmann must take the lead from Ron Paul...go after Perry on the negatives that he has. If she claims to be the righteous one, then she has the moral obligation to expose Perry...to do otherwise would be a disservice to our country.


Ms. Backmann's counterpart, Ms. Palin, was emphatic when she said all candidates must be vetted, implying scrutinized...it was shortly after Perry entered the presidential race...surely Palin's target was Perry.


Ms. Backmann did well standing up to Pawlenty in previous debates...it is probably her last chance to hold her own, taking on Perry at Monday's debate on CNN. A combo of Ron Paul and Bachmann taking on Perry may do the country some good before the guy gets traction.


Surely Perry is seen as the radical right of those seeking the nomination. The country will not go from one extreme (radical liberal Obama) to the other extreme (radical conservative Perry).

Ms. Bachmann faces two significant challenges in her Alice in Wonderland campaign for the GOP nomination. The first is Bachmann herself. It's glaringly obvious that she's not too bright and is hard-pressed to give a decent interview. Second, just above the glass ceiling are very powerful white men who will use all levels of devious and subtle means to ensure that she’s expeditiously dispatched from the race.

Part of me feels like this has something to do with the bond the city felt specifically with the Mets after 9/11 and the conspicuous absence of any Yankee presence in the relief effort. Sure a lot of it was the result of Shea being a natural staging area, but the Mets players really went all out and were visible and involved and (for whatever reason) the Yankees simply were not. If this is an attempt to circumvent any efforts by the Mets to celebrate their own history because it poses such a contrast to the billionaires in the Bronx who stayed home ... that would be shameful indeed Mr. Torre. The half-hearted wearing of 1st responder caps during warm ups in the world series was a lame gesture when you consider the incredible moment that the 1st game back against the Braves was for the entire city and that the Mets defied regulations and wore the caps anyway. Collins really blew it on this one ... he should have let them wear the caps.

As observed elsewhere, "Clearly a victory for Mr. Snyder. This settlement proves he is not narcissistic, punitive, small minded, selfish, money grubbing, incompetent, mean spirited, nor criminally minded. That he misshandled and abused the Redskins franchise is clearly an indication of his innate nobility, not a matter to be ridiculed."  And a  man who owns Redskins is not a racist.

Ms. Williams is, herself, "a hater". She's "out of control."

And most definitely, she is "unattractive inside."

Hmmm.  Red nail polish (Serena) during the Women's Final match.  No nail polish during the press conference following....  says something.  She is losing credibility - fast.  And I have been a loyal fan.

Federer does have a history of making sometimes ungracious remarks and remarks that strike me as being arrogant. But after I've won 16 slams and achieved what he has, I too would have an ego.
In any case, he didn't give Djokovich his due here, but I don't think he was questioning Djokovich's work ethic here. It seems just kind of an odd thing to say and then saying he was not always the hardest worker himself, etc. Just a stream of consciousness statement that I'm not sure even he really knows what he was trying to say. Haven't we all had those, even when it wasn't in the context of losing a match in a Grand Slam tournament and being interviewed in a roomful of reporters.
I'll give Fed a pass on this as frustration and probably being in a bit of a daze at having blown two match points again, one year after being in the same situation.
And yes, Fed clearly does not like Djokovich. When Fed was on top and all the other players treated him like a god, Djokovich was the one player who dared to say he felt he could beat Fed because he was just a human being. No idolizing on Djokovich's part, which is why he's had some success against Fed.

WOW, the "hatred" exhibited in so many of these comments about Serena runs deep. And it seems to be about a lot more than what happened today. It's unfortunate she lost that point, more unfortunate that she lost her temper. But, who hasn't lost it in the heat of a tense moment?!

I felt bad for Serena. I think she is a tremendous tennis player and I really enjoy watching her. Samantha Stosser was much the best today and played brilliantly. I saw good sportsmanship all around at the end of the match.

Julio Cesar should have stopped at least the second goal and really the 4th (that was a real dipper though), but if Inter want to find a reason for the loss it starts with Gasperini and that ridiculous 343. Barca can play this (and often do even when they don't line up that way) because their defense is conducted in the opponent's half. Zanetti, Lucio, and Samuel are strong defenders but are just too old and slow these days, especially for a 3 man defense, and so is Cambiasso screening. On the other end, the 3 person attack was barely 2.5 since Forlan was hardly involved, but if and when he does get involved that means that the squad is going to get stretched front to back (since the slow back line cannot press high) and there will be huge gaps all over the place. This was a problem Rafa and Leonardo never solved. Only Mourinho figured out that his only viable option was to sit deep, pack the defense, and play the counter (and that was with a 2 year younger back line). They really needed to get some youth in defense, and all they have is Ranocchia, who isn't quite ready yet. They got a ton of money from Eto'o and Pandev, and didn't fix a problem that's getting on three years old now.

I was also confused by the Zarate business. I can only guess Gasperini was sitting Sneijder and Pazzini for the CL match Wednesday against the world power that is Trabzonspor. Then again, if they play like this, Trabzonspor might give them more than they bargained for ...

On the plus side, that was a, um, reJuvenated Juventus Saturday. Pirlo looked like his old self. Hopefully they can keep this up.

Very astute!

CBS, you were saying?

Thanks for the article. I used to be Roger's fan and I believed he was a true genuine class. However i was bitterly disappointed when I learned he was only graceful in victory as he didn't lose much and I could not experience his other darker side of a sour loser. He is a great tennis player but has a fake gentleman's character. I always root against him as there are other genuine sportsmen on the tour, Novak being one of them. Great win for Novak!

For a more balance analysis of the "Shot" and Federer's response to it during his press conference, see: http://online.wsj.com/article/SB1000142405311190426550457656486241418853...

People are quick to criticize Federer. He has also said many wonderful things about Djokovic. You have to recognize his press conference was almost immediately after perhaps the toughest loss of his career, which was made tougher because he lost like this 2nd year in a row! Given him a break rather than parse his every word (when he was clearly upset at the loss) and judge his character on its basis. Frankly, both players deserved to win but there can be only one winner. Even Nadal said in his press conference, Federer was very unlucky not to win after having 2 match points on his serve.
